ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 8 and 10 It is Lecturer's first time teaching and I believe he will improve over time. He was able to communicate his thoughts clearly enough to my understanding.

This topic matter is so important to FES students (myself included). Unfortunately, Larry did not deliver that information in a comprehensible manner. I think this is "fixable" however he needs to build entirely new lecture slides, he needs to practice, and frankly he needs engaged TAs. (The TAs in this class let him down by not helping him with his lectures). Text only slides do not work. A scrambled lesson plan does not work. A syllabus that has no progression does not work. I was sorry to see this class fail, I was pretty excited for it when I saw the readings and the content description at first. Larry, I think you can improve as a lecturer and would love to see it happen, however for now I would strongly recommend no one take this course until it is ready.
Very slow class. Maybe add some material that arent on the slides. Reading the slides for 3 hours is not productive.
I struggled to follow much of what was taught, because of the the lecture style.

The course was a conglomeration of many courses and subject taught across FES and Yale. I'm having a hard time discerning what I already knew versus what I have taken away from the course. Not the case for everyone I'm sure. I would recommend this course be offered in the fall to first year students.

I did not gain much from this course. I felt that the course title was very misleading. I expected to learn about specific ways to invest in environmental problems, as was discussed in the guest lecture on water by Brad Gentry. Instead, I felt like this course summarized almost every concept I was learning in depth in other energy courses in a disjointed and poorly organized way. For example, we were assigned to read the exact same project documents that we were read and analyzed in depth in Renewable Project Finance, and this course offered nothing new and brushed over these seemingly unrelated topics. Additionally, while using legal tools to privately invest is what the course was supposed to be about, we didn't cover specific legal concepts (other than very broad concepts like externalities, etc that most people are already very familiar with) nor did we cover finance concepts. I'm not entirely sure what the intent of the course's structure was or what we were supposed to take away from it, other than a very basic understanding of concepts most of us already knew.

I answered very valuable to Question 12 because I think it has the potential to be very valuable, but it needs to be entirely re-formatted before it can provide value. The readings were way too much - the amount assigned was very discouraging. The powerpoints were way too text-heavy and the instructor merely read from the slides, which made it very hard to keep focus in class. One of the biggest disappointments of the class for me was the lack of variety in case studies and examples - they all focused on clean energy. Obviously investment in clean energy is very important, but a variety of examples would have been much more inclusive for other people's interests; after all, it is a class on legal concepts of private investment, not legal concepts of private investment in the energy sector. Also, energy projects are very confusing and for someone who is not in that field, I found the case studies very hard to follow because I did not know all of the language or logistics of a renewable project. Again, a couple of energy case studies would have been fine, but I would have really appreciated other examples of how legal concepts can affect private investment in other fields.

Understanding that Professor Rodman was teaching for the first time, I still thought that I got very little out of this course. He tried to pack extremely dense and complex legal material into each three hour seminar, preferring to lecture for the whole time rather than to actively engage students, many of whom had experience in the field he was lecturing about. He would just read from his notes honestly. Some of the guest lectures were great, though - from the Connecticut Green Bank for example. Professor Rodman was always available to talk on the phone about projects but less so face-to-face. I would have preferred this course if it were 1) Much more engaging - for example, if it were half lecture half practicum, or more questions directed to students and MUCH less material and 2) taught by a different professor - ideally somebody with more contact with environmental groups and issues that weren't only the realm of the extremely rich. There was little focus on small scale environmental conservation or environmental development in developing countries - it was entirely US centric, pulling examples from large industries like wind and solar, rather than, for example, examining conservation frameworks in Latin America. Many of the students in the class were not from the United States, and so having a broader perspective would have been more relevant for them.

The course material was not clearly organized so it felt like we were consistently learning the same lessons over and over rather than new aspects of the same concepts in a variety of applications. The instructor very clearly is passionate about the subject and I think once he gets more comfortable with these materials, the course will greatly benefit for his fluidity.
Too much overlap from Daniel Gross' class.

Question 8: Larry is spot on when it comes to teaching the legal material of the course, but when he tries to teach the economics or environmental components he definitely falls short. Recommend bringing in more guest lecturers to help fill these gaps. His choice of guest lecturers was excellent and I learned a lot.

Question 8 Lawrence Rodman is an excellent teacher. He knowledge of the material is strong and his discussion was engaging. His teaching improved greatly over the length of the course. The most interesting parts of the lecture were those that diverged from the power point script and delved into Larry's personal legal and investment experiences.

I felt like the entire class could have been cut down by half because there was, what felt like, a lot of repetition. There are only so many ways to say "minimize risk" that at a certain point it felt like beating a dead horse. I would have liked to have the material covered in the entire course to be covered in just the first half, cut out the repetition, and have the second half focused on actual examples, real-word strategies, and application. Dr. Gross's guest lecture on corporate structure and financing to drive investment is more along the lines of what I was anticipating the class to be.

To be very honest, this course has WAY too much reading and if anyone says the opposite he or she either doesn't do the reading or is lying. It is simply impossible to fit that much reading into a week for a student who takes classes and works. One may say just do the key reading, then what's the point of having so many reading listed in the first place? The lecture room is WAY to big for such a small class. I sometimes wonder if most of the students were present at all. PLEASE cut down the content and increase class discussion. There is no way anyone can retain that much material. Though the subject is understandably broad, there have to be areas of focus. Right now, the slides are extremely long and wordy and very boring to read. I wonder what the TAs are doing besides grading papers(?). They should spend some time beautifying those slides and make them conducive to learning. To be fair, this is the first time Lawrence is teaching so there's much room for improvement. He is very helpful when he is free but he has very little time to help during class (because he is rushing through slides, #1 pitfall for beginning teachers) and after class (rushing to catch a train home). The way he lectures is really just reading the slides, which are typed out in sentences broken into different lines. That sort of presentation can't fly in any investment/sales pitch. How can we learn private investment properly if the lecturer isn't setting a good example? Perhaps the Professional Communications Center at FES can help him to learn to present and deliver materials more effectively.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The real life application and examples of how to use the concepts in class.
The content is very important to environmental managers.
Larrys openness to being contacted outside of class. my talks with him about my project taught me more than the class did.
Instructor feedback on the course project. He is clearly an expert on legal issues.
Good content and important concepts to understand

Definitely the professor. He was the most willing professor i've had to meet with students and offer advice. You can also tell he really enjoyed teaching and interacting with students which was very nice to see.

I did very much appreciate Larry's willingness to help students on papers and give us individual attention. He was very helpful and really helped a lot of us shape our arguments for our paper. I think the papers were useful exercises as well, and I appreciate the idea of fostering our own creativity and using that in our papers.
I did like the idea of following through on an environmental issue throughout the semester and did learn about my topic extensively.
Answered in detail in the google survey
Delving in and writing the papers.
Guest lecturers, and the fact that Larry seemed to genuinely care about our learning. The readings were a bit too basic in the early weeks but got better later on.

The readings were very interesting. I see the financial world in a whole new way. The assignments were creative and useful. The papers assigned provided students an opportunity to apply newly gained knowledge to a personal interest. Larry made himself very accessible to the students for guidance on each assignment. His encouragement and enthusiasm were inspirational.

The guest presentations by Professor Gross and Peter Davidson were the best aspects of the course. Both lectures were focused on concrete examples and practical application, especially Professor Gross'.

The best aspect of this course was how responsive Larry was to students. He was extremely willing and available to meet with students outside of class to go over material or paper ideas. He genuinely wants the students to learn the material and enjoys discussing it one on one with the students.
The final project

The course content is really good combing both legal and financial tools in the environmental space. The class was well organized and the readings availed long before the classes. Relevant examples used Guest lectures
Course material and course structure. Evaluation is focused on area-of-interest which is the best part.
It covers many topics though I doubt I remember much (to be perfectly honest...). Lawrence is very helpful outside of class but less so in class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Delivery of the lecture materials in class.
See my answer to Q13.

Presentation skills - lecturing in general. There is an entertainment factor and/or a role to be played by the lecturer. Facilitating questions and incorporating student insight might be useful going forward. Also the space was too large for the type of course offered. The format required a more intimate classroom setting.
Seems too broad-- some lectures could be more specific. Unsure of the narrative tying the different lectures together into a cohesive point for the course

The lectures could be improved. The slides were all a wall of text that he would read from during the entire class which can make it difficult to keep paying attention. I did see that he did work to ask questions and make it a little bit more of a discussion at the end. Doing this more would likely improve lectures. There was also way too much reading. Although it was optional, seeing a huge wall of text did stop me from doing the readings as it just seemed like a drop in the bucket.

As I said above, this course needs to be more focused and give more substantial content. I would've liked to learn about financial tools and more in-depth legal concepts rather than a very broad overview of these things.
See answer to Question 13 above.

1. Teaching style: his style was extremely dry and non-engaging. 2. Material: Please expand to not only delve into the US context and have more depth on conservation finance, which is why most of the people in this course decided to take it!
Very bland

The take home midterm and final were not helpful at all. The prompts were way too vague, the length too long, and the feedback was not helpful. Would have been great to have had smaller more concrete assignments and maybe a group project.
The power points could be simplified and reduced. The room where the class was held should have been smaller for the class size.

There was too much material to cover for each day. Many times I felt like Professor Rodman was rushed to cover the material in the allotted time and questions/discussions by the students had to be cut short for the sake of time. The way the material is presented also needs work. The slides were mostly just bullet notes with no diagrams, figures, ect, just words, and Professor Rodman would just read off the slides.
The lectures were quite long and after the first 1.5 hours it became hard to stay focused.
Lectures were not very smooth. It was clear that it was the first time Larry had taught this course, but I expect it would run better next year now that he has some teaching experience.
The delivery of the content Student engagement-it was quite low Clarity of concepts to be improved

Course is too vast. Needs to be divided into 2 parts - Legal Framework & Investment. It has to be offered only for second years (Fall semester) so that most students would have already acquired basic financial, investment and environmental concepts and are ready to absorb the legal frameworks. Legal framework is focused on U.S. Since the scope of environmental investments and hence the course are not limited to USA, the legal frameworks of other countries (especially China, India and African nations) could also be discussed with equal rigor. I would like to see atleast 30% times allocated for discussion of legal frameworks in different countries. This could be done through participatory approaches or systematic case studies. I think this could become a star-course of FES if - Focus of the course is only legal tools 30-40% of the time is given for international legal frameworks (with constant comparison with that of US)

Lawrence really needs to upgrade the slides to conform with our modern presentation standard and present the material as further away from reading the slides as possible. His TAs need to take a more proactive role in class (and perhaps he should let them...). There is a dire need for class discussion and a focus in the curriculum to engage further learning.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Guest lectures were very very effective. I have learnt a lot through guest lectures. My mind was engaged with some of the best ideas in the environment investment space. But I didn't feel the same about the legal tools. I have heard a lot of legal tools (jargon) but did not digest them well!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Useful info-- but repetitive with several other courses taken
My focus is on conservation finance so this topic in general is very central.
Helps me develop better idea of legal structure to starting a "green"company and getting money for that company run
This course was good for a basic understanding of private investment. However maybe it's better to just take a course at SOM.

This material is essential to the implementation of any environmental business strategy. Though I'm not sure I will need to seek investment support for a future business, I am stronger in my field from knowledge gained about legal tools, and the balancing of risks and returns for business growth.

Over the years the main source of funds for addressing environmental issues had been public funds and in developing countries direct foreign funding. This is however slowly changing as private organizations/individuals come into this space. This class gives an insight into the legal aspects involved when investing in environmental issues such as property rights. It also highlights the organizational structures through which this funds can be channeled such as limited companies, partnerships, corporations and the emerging forms such as B Corps. This knowledge is useful in understanding investments in the environment but more how to st up organizations that are able to attract other peoples money to protect the environment,for example in the renewable energy sector which is my area of interest.
Course is very useful for my area of focus at YES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To understand the legal issues around environmental investment at various stages of impact.
I have some experience, and was hoping to get some further insight and perhaps even answer some legal questions that currently plague environmental markets/finance and strategy.
I took this course to get an introduction to private investment in the environment, in order to better understand how the private sector can pick up the public sector slack in conservation finance.
To learn how to finance green tech
I wanted a primer on private investment tools.
The reading list was interesting and the assignments gave me a chance to explore personal interests.
I took the course because I had no understanding of private investment at all.

I took the course to understand what drives people to invest their money in environmental protection,what returns do they expect, what are the legal instruments at play when undertaking such investments and what are their limitation and what is the role of the government when it comes to private investments
To become an environment investor in the near future.
I wanted to learn more about private investment and legal tools.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
No, I do not feel like I have any new knowledge or skills.
No.
I think assignments other than papers-- perhaps a group presentation or other interactive final project would have better helped me unify the concepts
It seemed that the course covered too much information, making it seem a bit diluted. Maybe keeping the content a bit more focused with more in depth analysis on particular points would be good.
No. I expected to have a better understanding of investment tools and strategies.
No. I came out of the class not having picked up much at all; much of what I learned was from my classmates explaining concepts to me on their own time.

Not in the slightest. I cannot name a single skill that I gained from this course. In terms of knowledge, I guess I got an introduction into legal frameworks that are relevant to the environment, but this is something I could have gotten from a law school class, not a forestry class.
Unfortunately, they did not.
I didn't think it would be so law focused
I thought I would learn more concrete investment tools by using spreadsheets, but overall I still learned a fair amount so the course did meet my expectation to a certain degree.
The knowledge gained exceeded my expectations.
No. Again, I was anticipating the class to be more like Professor Gross's guest lecture.

Yes. We were able to systematically go through the legal concepts around things such as property rights around tangibles(water,land) and intangibles (intellectual property) and their limitations in conserving the environment. We also discussed in detail the different organizational structures,their merits and demerits and how this impacts how investors think. We were also able to see the market failures arising from investing in the environment and ways to address this failures, which highlighted the roles of the government.

Not completely. Investment concepts - To a decent extent - most of my learning was through guest lectures Legal tools - Still confused with many concepts since legal system of USA is not my area of interest.
Not enough. My retention rate is low even though I attend every class. It's hard to retain knowledge when I was passively fed a lot of materials that are overbroad every week for three hours.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We didn't have any group exercise

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do not take this course.

There are other finance/environmental/legal courses that incorporate many of the lectures covered in this class, and might be more useful to take those other classes. Too much content is packed into this course - I believe a little goes a long way, especially considering FES is likely to have overlap on the same issues/topics concerning the environment.
Do not take this course.
Take it if you have interest in helping green companies get money.

Attend all the guest lectures! The readings are pretty helpful too. Don't spend too much time stressing about the midterm and final you'll get the same grade no matter how much or how little effort you invest.
Read and skim as much of the reading list as you can. Take advantage of access to Larry Rodman. His guidance is essential to connecting personal interests with subject material.
If you are self-motivated this class could be very useful to you.

The course content is really good but may require extensive reading. There is lots to learn especially the legal aspects and you don't have to have any prior background in law for this. The class is quite diverse and interesting.

THis course has brilliant design. Highly advisable to those whose primary source of knowledge is course material. Also take the course if you have a good business idea in energy at the beginning of the course.
